Project Description  The Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Ha Noi–Lang Son, GMS 
Ha  Long–Mong  Cai,  and  Ben  Luc–Long  Thanh  Expressways 
Technical  Assistance  (TA)  Project  (the  TA  Loan  Project)  is  to 
provide  assistance  to  the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  and  the 
Vietnam  Expressway  Corporation  (VEC)  in  implementing 
preconstruction activities of the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son, the GMS 
Ha Long–Mong Cai, and the Ben Luc–Long Thanh expressway 
projects,  including  (i)  development  of  detailed  designs  of  the 
expressways  and  their  associated  facilities;  (ii)  update  of 
resettlement plans, ethnic minority development plans (EMDPs) or 
ethnic  minority  specific  actions  (EMSAs),  and  environmental 
impact  assessments  (EIAs)  and  environmental  management 
plans (EMPs); (iii) preparation of bidding documents for civil works 
and  assistance  during  the  procurement  of  contracts;  and 
(iv) assistance  with  implementation  of  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement for the three expressway projects.  
   
Rationale  The economy of Viet Nam has been growing rapidly, with gross 
domestic product (GDP) growing at an average annual rate of 
7.5% from 2001 to 2005, and it is expected to grow more rapidly, 
at an average annual rate of 10%, up to 2010. Traffic volume will 
double within 7–8 years. Development of transport infrastructure, 
especially the expressway network, is essential to achieve rapid 
economic growth. The TA Loan Project will assist the Government 
and  VEC  in  preparing  the  following  high-priority  expressway 
projects: (i) the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son Expressway, to be linked 
with  the  existing  Nanning–Youyiguan  Expressway  in  Guangxi 
Zhuang Autonomous Region (GZAR) in the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC); (ii) the GMS Ha Long–Mong Cai Expressway, to be 
linked with the planned Fangcheng–Dongxing Expressway in the 
GZAR;  and  (iii)  the  Ben  Luc–Long  Thanh  Expressway,  to 
strengthen connectivity in the southern suburbs of Ho Chi Minh 
City  (HCMC).  These  expressways  are  all  part  of  the  GMS 
economic corridors identified in the GMS transport sector strategy 
study endorsed by the GMS governments in May 2006.

ii   
Impact and Outcome  Through  implementation  of  the  TA  Loan  Project,  the  three 
expressway  projects  will  be  designed  and  prepared  for 
investment. The expressways will promote the efficient movement 
of goods and people between northeastern Viet Nam and GZAR, 
and  within  the  greater  HCMC  area.  Ultimately,  the  TA  Loan 
Project  will  contribute  to  sustainable  economic  growth  and 
enhanced economic exchange between Viet Nam and the PRC, 
and  promote  socioeconomic  development  in  the  project-
influenced areas.

including taxes and duties of $4.3 million.

expressway alignments, and preparing and implementing the land 
acquisition  and  resettlement  activities  and  the  livelihood 
development and income restoration programs.

iii
Consulting Services  For  each  expressway  project,  the  following  four  kinds  of 
consulting  services  will  be  undertaken:  (i)  project  feasibility 
consulting services, to be funded by the associated TA grants, will 
prepare  engineering,  economic,  financial,  social,  and 
environmental  feasibility  studies;  (ii)  project  design  consulting 
services, to be funded by the TA loan, will (a) prepare detailed 
designs, (b) update resettlement plans, EMDPs (or EMSAs), EIAs 
and EMPs based on the detailed designs, and (c) assist in the 
procurement  of  civil  works  and  the  implementation  of  land 
acquisition  and  resettlement;  (iii)  detailed  design  appraisal 
consulting services, to be funded by the TA loan, will review the 
detailed designs and project cost estimates in accordance with the 
Government’s internal procedures; and (iv) external resettlement 
monitoring consulting services, to be funded by the TA loan.  
 
ADB  will  recruit  international  consulting  firms  for  the  project 
feasibility study, using quality- and cost-based selection (QCBS) 
procedures, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  VEC  will 
recruit international consulting firms for the project design study 
using  QCBS  procedures  and  for  the  detailed  design  appraisal 
study using QCBS or consultants’ qualifications selection (CQS) 
procedures,  and  national  consulting  firms  for  the  external 
resettlement  monitoring  using  QCBS  or  CQS  procedures,  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.  
   
Project Benefits and  The  TA  Loan  Project  will  produce  direct  benefits  such  as  (i) 
Beneficiaries  preparing the subsequent expressway projects to high technical 
and safeguard standards; (ii) implementing the ensuing projects 
without unnecessary delay; and (iii) improving VEC’s capacity for 
project management, detailed design of expressways, corporate 
financial  management,  procurement,  and  safeguard 
arrangements. The expressways, to be constructed based on the 
outputs of the TA Loan Project, will provide efficient, safe, and 
reliable express routes for the movement of goods and people 
between northeastern Viet Nam and GZAR, and within the greater 
HCMC area. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The main risk for the TA Loan Project is implementation delay 
caused by project internal and external factors. The consultant 
selection  process  and  decision-making  process  on  the 
expressway alignments are potential causes for implementation 
delays. These will be addressed by providing VEC with specialist 
support.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
technical assistance (TA) loan to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Greater Mekong 
Subregion (GMS) Ha Noi–Lang Son, GMS Ha Long–Mong Cai, and Ben Luc–Long Thanh 
Expressways Technical Assistance Project (the TA Loan Project). The report also describes (i) 
proposed  TA  grant  for  preparing  the  GMS  Ha  Noi–Lang  Son  and  Ha  Long–Mong  Cai 
expressway  projects,  and  (ii)  proposed  TA  grant  for  preparing  the  Ben  Luc–Long  Thanh 
Expressway Project, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority 
delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA grants. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  The economy of Viet Nam has been growing rapidly, with gross domestic product (GDP) 
growing at an average annual rate of 7.5% from 2001 to 2005, and expected accelerated growth 
of 10% annually up to 2010. Traffic volume will double within 7–8 years. Development of 
transport  infrastructure,  especially  the  expressway  network,  is  essential  to  achieve  rapid 
economic  growth.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  provided  funding  to  assist  the 
Government in preparing an expressway master plan for the national expressway system.1 The 
plan identifies a logical national network with a total length of about 5,000 kilometers (km). 
Based on economic and financial viability, priority is given to the expressway network with high 
capacity  that  will  connect  key  economic  and  industrial  zones,  large  urban  centers,  and 
international  borders.  In  the  expressway  master  plan,  construction  of  about  2,000  km 
expressway will have commenced by 2015, and 500 km of expressway will be open to public 
traffic by 2015. 
 
3.  Out of the priority expressway network, the Government of Viet Nam has requested ADB 
to consider financing the construction of (i) the Ha Noi–Lang Son Expressway (about 120 km) 
and the Ha Long–Mong Cai Expressway (about 120 km) in the northern region (Map 1), which 
are  key  sections  of  the  GMS  eastern  corridor  linking  Viet  Nam  and  Guangxi  Zhuang 
Autonomous Region (GZAR) in the People’s Republic of China (PRC); and (ii) the Ben Luc–
Long Thanh Expressway (about 60 km) in the south of Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC) (Map 2), 
which is a key section of the GMS southern corridor which links Viet Nam, Cambodia, and 
Thailand, and intersects with the GMS eastern corridor (Map 3). This TA Loan Project, with 
associated TA grants, will prepare the three expressway projects. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. The regional dimension of the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son and Ha 
Long–Mong Cai Expressways is summarized in Appendix 2. 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
4.  The GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son Expressway is proposed to be constructed parallel to 
National Highway No.1 (NH1), which was upgraded under the ADB-assisted Second Road 
Improvement Project,2 as well as to the single-track railway in northern Viet Nam leading to

GZAR. The distance between Ha Noi and the border town of Huu Nghi in Lang Son province is 
about 130 km. The GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son Expressway forms part of the GMS eastern corridor,

shifted to the improved NH1. On average, eight freight trains run per week, transporting mainly 
heavy materials and products such as ore and steel. It is less likely, therefore, that there will be 
a modal shift arising from the construction of the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son Expressway.  
 
5.  The existing NH18 runs along the northern coast from Ha Long to Mong Cai, through 
Mong Duong. It is identified as a priority GMS transport project under the TSSS. The distance 
between Ha Long and Mong Cai is about 200 km. NH18 has four lanes in city areas and two 
lanes in other places. The road is generally in good condition, except for a 10–20 km section 
from Mong Cai, which is in poor condition. It currently takes 6 hours to drive from Ha Long to 
Mong Cai. NH18 is being used as a heavy freight route, with an estimated 500 truck-trailers 
carrying 40-foot maritime containers using it each day. Hai Phong port in northern Viet Nam 
serves as a gateway for the PRC in importing goods from other Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations (ASEAN) countries. The containers arrive at Hai Phong port and are immediately 
transported to GZAR. The geometric alignment of NH18 is within acceptable standards, but 
curve radius and lane width are considered too sharp and narrow for truck-trailers; many traffic 
accidents occur on this road. It has many short bridges with a load limit of 13 tons, and these 
bridges are damaged by truck-trailers carrying 40-foot maritime containers. NH18 is also being 
used as a tourism route. Passenger bus services have been developed, but there is no railway 
service. In this regard, a new expressway of acceptable design standards should be considered 
in order to reduce travel time and transport costs, improve road safety in the influence area of 
NH18, promote tourism, and maintain the road assets of NH18. The use of NH18 as a long-term 
freight route, however, remains uncertain, as three major ports in GZAR are being expanded by 
the GZAR authority. Therefore it is important to carefully carry out transport and trade analyses, 
survey  related  infrastructure  development  in  the  influence  area,  and  conduct  traffic  flow 
assessments between Viet Nam and GZAR along this route.

expressway as well as a short link of the north–south expressway in Viet Nam, and will be 
connected to the planned HCMC–Vung Tau Expressway. The expressway forms part of the

produced in the Mekong Delta to the rest of the country by land and maritime transport.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
7.  Appendix 3 provides an analysis of the road subsector. Goals in the sector road map set 
out in 2006 are being achieved. Major issues in the road subsector are insufficient highway 
capacity and high accident rates. In parallel with economic growth and income increase, traffic 
demand for roads and traffic volume on roads has rapidly increased. For example, on NH1 
between Ha Noi, Lang Son, and Huu Nghi (the border with the PRC), average annual traffic 
growth of 87% was recorded on the section between Ha Noi and Cao Beng; growth of 21% was 
recorded on the section between Bac Giang and Lang Son; and growth of 37% was recorded on the 
section between Lang Son and Huu Nghi, from April 2001 to July 2003.5 Road fatalities and 
(cid:31)F
injuries in Viet Nam rapidly increased in the late 1990s, although this increase stopped in 2002, 
and the number of injuries from traffic accidents has substantially dropped since then. However, 
the number of fatalities from traffic accidents remains high, at 12,000–13,000 per year during 
2003–2007. The traffic accident rate for access-controlled highways is much lower than that for 
access-free  roads.  The  development  of  high-design-standard  expressways  is  expected  to 
improve road safety. Expressway network development will address these issues efficiently. 
 
8.  The GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son Expressway will be connected with the existing Nanning–
Youyiguan Expressway in GZAR at the Huu Nghi–Youyiguan border. The GMS Ha Long–Mong 
Cai Expressway will be connected with the planned Fangcheng–Dongxing Expressway in GZAR 
at the Mong Cai–Dongxing border. The demand for international freight traffic along these 
corridors is  high.  However,  the  current  slow  and cumbersome  border  crossing  operations, 
including the need for transshipment between Vietnamese and Chinese trucks at these borders, 
are bottlenecks to international trade. It takes at least 3 days to forward cargo from Nanning to 
Ha Noi by truck. Transport facilitation measures provided for under the GMS cross-border 
transport agreement (CBTA), which has been ratified by the governments of Viet Nam and the 
PRC, will help remove these impediments and further boost two-way trade between Viet Nam 
and GZAR.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
19.  The  ensuing  expressway  projects  will  construct  (i)  the  GMS  Ha  Noi–Lang  Son 
Expressway  (about  120  km),  which  will  be  connected  to  the  existing  Nanning–Youyiguan 
Expressway in GZAR; (ii) the GMS Ha Long–Mong Cai Expressway (about 120 km), which will 
be connected to the existing Nanning–Fangcheng Expressway and the Fangcheng–Dongxing 
highway in GZAR; and (iii) the Ben Luc–Long Thanh Expressway (about 60 km), which will form 
part of the outer ring road of the HCMC urban expressway, and be an access link with the 
planned HCMC–Vung Tau Expressway. The outcome of the TA Loan Project is the design of 
the ensuing expressway projects agreed to by the Government of Viet Nam, VEC, ADB, and 
cofinanciers. 
 
20.  The expected impact of the TA Loan Project is the achievement of efficient movement of 
goods and people between northeastern Viet Nam and GZAR, and within the greater HCMC 
area, through construction of the three expressways. International and local traffic will be able to 
use an efficient, safe, and reliable express route from Ha Noi to the border with the PRC 
through  the  completion  of  the  GMS  Ha  Noi–Lang  Son  and  GMS  Ha  Long–Mong  Cai 
expressways. Connectivity of cities and towns around HCMC will be improved and the cost and 
travel times for the movement of passengers and goods in and around HCMC will be reduced 
through completion of the Ben Luc–Long Thanh Expressway. Ultimately, the TA Loan Project 
will contribute to sustainable economic growth and enhanced economic exchange between Viet 
Nam and the PRC, and promote socioeconomic development in the project-influenced areas.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
43.  This project preparatory TA package, combining the project feasibility study and project 
design study, will help the Government and VEC ensure economic and financial viability of the 
large-scale  infrastructure  projects,  and  mitigate  social  and  environmental  risks  caused  by 
implementation of the projects. Moreover, compared to the standard processing scheme, which 
provides a TA loan for project design study after TA for the project feasibility study is completed, 
the physical works would be able to commence more than 1 year earlier. In Viet Nam, project 
executing agencies cannot start consultant recruitment actions before the project loans are 
approved.  Under  this  project  preparatory  TA  package,  ADB  will  take  advance  contracting 
actions for the consulting services on the project feasibility study to be funded by the associated 
TA grants, and VEC will start consultant recruitment for the project design study to be funded by 
the TA loan after ADB approves the TA Loan Project with the associated TA grants.  
 
44.  The main risk for the TA Loan Project is implementation delay caused by project internal 
and external factors. The consultant selection process is a potential cause for implementation 
delay. VEC will start selection of the consultant for the project design study immediately after 
approval of the TA Loan Project. The decision-making process on the expressway alignments is 
another potential cause for implementation delay. The consultants for the project feasibility 
study will propose expressway alignments based on engineering difficulty, construction cost, 
and social and environmental impacts. MOT and VEC will have consultation meetings on the 
expressway  alignments  with  representatives  from  the  project  provinces,  districts,  and 
communes. The general alignment should be determined before the detailed design study 
starts.

projects, it will not cause any adverse social impacts. The resettlement and indigenous peoples 
impact categories for the TA Loan Project are classified as category C. However, construction of 
the  expressways  (under  the  ensuing  project  loans)  will  require  significant  involuntary 
resettlement, including relocation of houses and loss of agricultural and residential land. The 
general expressway alignments will be provided under the associated TA projects, paying 
attention  to  potential  negative  social  impacts.  The  associated  TA  projects  will  prepare  a 
resettlement plan, and an EMDP (or an EMSA) for each expressway project, and the TA Loan

Loan Project is provided in Appendix 12.

E.  Cross-Border Transport Facilitation in the Greater Mekong Subregion 
 
14.  The  GMS  governments  have  recognized  that  providing  subregional  physical 
infrastructure is a necessary but not a sufficient condition for increased connectivity among the 
six GMS countries. Mitigating nonphysical barriers to the cross-border movement of goods and 
people is important to increase efficiency, reduce costs, and maximize the economic benefits of 
improved subregional transport infrastructure. Nonphysical barriers impeding the free movement 
of  vehicles,  goods,  and  people  across  international  borders  in  the  subregion  include 
(i) restrictions  on  the  entry  of  motor  vehicles,  often  causing  costly  and  time-consuming 
transshipment;  (ii)  different  standards  pertaining  to  vehicle  size,  weight,  and  safety 
requirements,  and  driver  qualifications;  (iii)  inconsistent  and  difficult  formalities  related  to 
customs procedures, inspections, clearances, and assessment of duties; (iv) restrictive visa 
requirements;  and  (v)  inadequate  border  crossing  infrastructure  and  facilities.  Bilateral 
agreements on cross-border movement exist between many GMS members. These agreements, 
however,  only  partly  address  critical  cross-border  facilitation  issues,  and  hinder  transit 
movement  of  vehicles,  goods,  and  people  to  third  countries.  In  addition,  the  bilateral 
agreements existing among pairs of GMS countries are not necessarily consistent with each 
other and run the risk of having gaps and overlaps, thereby making transport facilitation even 
more difficult. Therefore, a multilateral framework to facilitate the cross-border movement of 
goods and people on a subregion-wide and consistent basis is necessary to allow for both 
interstate and transit traffic. 
 
15.  To mitigate nonphysical barriers to the cross-border movement of goods and people in 
the  GMS,  the  six  countries  have  negotiated,  signed,  and  ratified  a  cross-border  transport 
agreement (CBTA). The GMS CBTA is a multilateral instrument for the facilitation of cross-
border transport of goods and people. Formulated under the auspices of a series of ADB 
technical  assistance  projects,  the  CBTA  provides  a  practical  approach  to  streamlining 
regulations and reducing nonphysical barriers in the GMS. It incorporates the principles of 
bilateral or multilateral actions, and flexibility in recognition of differences in procedures in each

Appendix 2  25 
of the GMS countries. The implementing guidelines of the CBTA have all been signed, and are 
expected to be ratified in 2008. Full implementation of the CBTA is expected to commence in 
2010.  
 
16.   The CBTA covers all the relevant aspects of cross-border transport facilitation in one 
document. These include (i) single-stop single-window customs inspection; (ii) cross-border 
movement of persons (i.e., visas for persons engaged in transport operations); (iii) transit traffic 
regimes, including exemptions from physical customs inspection, bond deposit, escort, and 
agriculture and veterinary inspection; (iv) requirements that road vehicles will have to meet to be 
eligible  for  cross-border  traffic  status;  (v)  exchange  of  commercial  traffic  rights;  and  (vi) 
infrastructure, including road and bridge design standards, road signs, and signals. The CBTA 
will apply to selected and mutually agreed upon routes and points of entry and exit in the 
signatory countries. A memorandum of understanding between Viet Nam and the PRC was 
signed in March 2008 by vice-ministers of transport of the two countries to include the Ha Noi–
Lang Son corridor and the Huu Nghi–Youyiguan border crossings in the scope of the CBTA. 
 
17.   A  bilateral  road  transport  agreement  between  Viet  Nam  and  the  PRC  is  in  effect 
between the two countries, but its scope limits access for trucks in one country to only the 
border areas of the other country. Likewise, the costs incurred and time to clear the border 
checkpoint account for a significant portion of the total transport cost and time. When the CBTA 
enters into force between the PRC and Viet Nam, i.e., when both governments ratify the CBTA’s 
implementing  guidelines,  key  transport  facilitation  provisions  mentioned  above  will  be 
implemented, and the current exchange of traffic rights arrangements that is limited to the 
border areas will be expanded to cover the entire Nanning–Ha Noi corridor.

C.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The expected impact of the TA is efficient transnational movement of goods and people 
between Viet Nam and GZAR through the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son and Ha Long–Mong Cai 
expressway projects. Together with a network of expressways linking Ha Noi and Kunming, and 
Kunming and Nanning, the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son and Ha Long–Mong Cai Expressways will 
complete an “economic triangle” connecting key development centers in Viet Nam and the PRC. 
This economic triangle in the northeastern part of the GMS will support the GMS program’s 
strategic objectives of enhanced connectivity, competitiveness, and community in the GMS. 
 
9.  Together with detailed design studies to be carried out under the associated TA loan 
project,  the  TA  will  result  in  the  identification  of  economically,  technically,  socially,  and 
environmentally feasible expressway projects that will link northeastern Viet Nam with GZAR, 
which will be agreed by the Government of Viet Nam, VEC, and ADB. Under the TA, technical 
feasibility  analyses  and  assessments  will  be  carried  out,  including  (i)  expressway  general 
alignment, (ii) cost-effective project design, (iii) evaluation of economic feasibility and financial 
viability, and (iv) social and environmental viability for the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son and Ha Long–
Mong Cai expressway projects.

10.  Given the strong regional dimensions of the two expressway projects, the TA will give 
special  emphasis  to  cross-border  aspects,  including  transport  and  trade  facilitation, 
competitiveness and complementarities of freight transportation from a multimodal perspective,

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
Viet Nam’s record in poverty reduction has been impressive in the last decade. The proportion of the population below the 
poverty line has declined from around 59% in 1993 to 25% in 2005. The proposed target for the Five-Year Socio-Economic 
Development Plan (2006–2010) is to reduce poor households to 15%–16% by 2010. While significant in terms of magnitude, 
progress in poverty reduction remains fragile, with a significant number of “near poor” clustered just above the poverty line. 
Sustained development requires modernization and improvement of physical infrastructure and associated services. 
 
Expressways are intended to serve long-distance traffic. They do not necessarily benefit local communities directly, but 
address poverty in areas around the expressway indirectly by facilitating continued economic growth. The proposed three 
expressways are crossing areas with very different rates and types of poverty.  
 
However, improved transport infrastructure is critical for sustained rapid economic growth and overall poverty reduction, and 
can contribute to regionally balanced and equitable economic growth by stimulating agriculture production, increasing access 
to employment opportunities, and facilitating better access to social services.  
 
According to the Vietnam Poverty Update Report 2006,a considerable investment in infrastructure is widely believed to have 
contributed to raising people’s welfare and to reducing poverty. The lack of infrastructure is recognized as a major reason for 
the high rate of poverty in the rural and remote isolated localities, and good efforts have been made in this area to promote 
more inclusive development in Viet Nam, rather than leaving part of the population disconnected from the mainstream of 
economic growth. Improved road connectivity under the proposed Project might contribute to poor people’s ability to benefit 
from economic growth in the long run. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
1.  Key Issues  
Considerable progress has been made in reducing poverty in Viet Nam. According to the Vietnam Poverty Update Report 
2006, the largest improvement was in the northeast region, including Lang Son and Quang Ninh provinces (crossed by the 
GMS Ha Noi–Lang Song and Ha Long–Mong Cai Expressways) where the incidence of poverty fell from 86% in 1993 to 29% 
in 2004, a reduction of 57 percentage points over 11 years. There was similarly rapid poverty reduction in the Red River Delta 
region, including Bac Giang Province (the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son Expressway), where the incidence of poverty fell by 51 
percentage points during the same period, from 63% in 1993 to 12% in 2004. In the southeast region, including Ho Chi Minh 
City and Dong Nai Province (the Ben Luc–Long Thanh Expressway) the incidence of poverty fell by 32 percentage points 
between 1993 and 2004. By 2004, poverty in the southeast region was only 5%. 
 
However, some pockets of poverty can be found along the northern projects in rural and mountainous areas. In Bac Giang 
province (Lang Giang, Viet Yen, and Yen Dung districts), the incidence of poverty is between 16% and 23.5%. In Lang Son 
province (Huu Lung, Cao Loc, and Chi Lang districts), the incidence of poverty is between 18% and 27%. In Quang Ninh 
province (Hai Ha, Dam Ha, and Tien Yen districts), the incidence of poverty is above 20%; while in the mountainous Ba Che 
district, half of the population is living below the poverty line. For the Ben Luc–Long Thanh Expressway, all the districts 
crossed have an incidence of poverty below 10%. 
 
It is important to note that the road network has been considerably improved in all the project areas during the last 10 years.  
 
Between Ha Noi and Lang Son, National Highway No.1 (NH1) has been improved in 2001 under an ADB-financed project.b 
NH1 follows mainly a new alignment. The new NH1 has reduced the travel time from the border to Ha Noi from 5.5 hours to 
2.5 hours. In addition, the rural road component of the project was designed to improve 600 kilometers (km) of selected 
provincial and district roads, in particular in Bac Giang and Lang Son provinces. Therefore, the proposed Project will have 
limited impact on poverty reduction in Bac Giang and Lang Son provinces in comparison with the impacts, due to the 
rehabilitation of NH1 and the improvement of rural roads.  
 
In Quang Ninh province, National Highway No.18 (NH18) from Cam Pha to Mong Cai has also been rehabilitated. However, 
NH18 is in constant need of repairs due to heavy vehicle traffic and also suffers from poor design standards imposed by the

56  Appendix 12 
topography of the area through which it passes. According to the Government’s prefeasibility study,c the three proposed 
alignment options will have positive impacts on poverty reduction, especially in the poor mountainous districts (Ba Che and 
Tien Yen districts in particular). The linking of these districts to the future expressway should be carefully studied during the 
TA Loan Project, whatever the alignment option chosen.  
 
For the Ben Luc–Long Thanh Expressway Project, the project area is already served by a good highway and even 
expressway network. In addition, the incidence of poverty is under 10% in all the districts crossed by the proposed 
expressway. Given the generally low rates of poverty in the project area, the proposed project will have very limited impact on 
poverty reduction in the project locations. The improvement of infrastructure will increase investment, growth of industry, and 
commerce in the project provinces. Through this economic growth, it is anticipated that employment opportunities of the poor 
in the project provinces could be increased. 
 
2. Design Features.  
The expressways will have auxiliary facilities, such as bus stops and service areas (michi-no-eki), that the local people living 
along the expressways could use. The project design study will include site selection and detailed designs of these facilities. 
Other  opportunities  for  pro-poor  design,  such  as  employment  generation  during  constriction,  will  be  explored  during 
implementation of the TA Loan Project. 
 
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
Profile of the Beneficiaries 
For a major highway project, there are no beneficiaries specifically targeted at the community level. The project is for the 
benefit of the wider society through the contacts, goods, services, and mobility which it provides. Its social and economic 
impacts, furthermore, are diffuse and cannot always be anticipated or controlled. As indicated above, the three project areas 
(in particular GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son and the Ben Luc–Long Thanh Expressways) benefit now from good rural road, highway, 
and expressway networks, which have considerably improved the living standards of the local population.  
 
For the three expressway projects, benefits will be found mainly at the regional and national levels, rather than the local level, 
except in Quang Ninh province where the proposed GMS Ha Long–Mong Cai Expressway will contribute to the development 
of some remote areas.  
 
The profile of beneficiaries for the three expressway projects is currently unknown; it will depend upon the option chosen for 
the different projects. The profile of primary and secondary beneficiaries, poor and vulnerable groups, and their needs, 
demands, constraints, and capacity will have to be identified during the implementation of the TA Loan Project. The 
socioeconomic profile of the population disaggregated by ethnicity and gender in the project area will be prepared as well as 
the social impact analysis along with the resettlement impact.   
  
Ethnic Minorities 
The presence of various ethnic minority groups is one of the main characteristics, especially for the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son 
Expressway Project, and, to a lesser extent, for the GMS Ha Long–Mong Cai Expressway Project. For the Ben Luc–Long 
Thanh Expressway Project, few ethnic minorities are present. 
 
Ethnic minority groups account for a large part of the population in the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son Expressway Project area. The 
three main ethnic groups present in the project area are the Nung, the Tay, and the Kinh (major ethnicity in Viet Nam). In 
Lang Son province, ethnic minority groups account for 86% of the population, and in Bac Giang province, they account for 
26%. In Lang Son province, the Nung account for 43% of the total population, the Tay 36%, and the Kinh 17%. Due to the 
large majority of ethnic minorities in the project area, ethnic minorities are found everywhere (urban areas, valleys, and 
mountains). The Kinh, however, are concentrated on the plains and in urban areas. Ethnic minorities are involved in all 
economic activities in the project area, and along the project corridor; there is no economic difference between Kinh and non-
Kinh.  
For the GMS Ha Long–Mong Cai Expressway Project, the major ethnic groups, the Kinh account for 95% of the population in 
Quang Ninh province, and the percentage of the ethnic minority groups is only 5%. However in some of the districts crossed 
by the different project options, the percentage of ethnic minority groups is much higher. The mountainous Ba Che district has 
by far the highest percentage (nearly 75%) of its population belonging to ethnic minority groups. Tien Yen district has also a 
high percentage (42%) of population belonging to ethnic minority groups. This district is crossed by the three options. Poverty 
is also more prevalent among ethnic minority groups than the Kinh majority. For the whole province, the incidence of poverty 
is 7.2% among the entire population but reaches 28.5% among the ethnic minority population.  
Few ethnic minority groups are present in the Ben Luc–Long Thanh Expressway Project area where they represent less than

Appendix 12       57     
1% of the population of the affected districts. In addition, the Hoa, the main ethnic group present in the project area, usually 
have a better living standard than that of other ethnic minorities.  
During the implementation of the TA Loan Project, the resettlement and other related impacts of the Project will be assessed 
for the three expressways. Accordingly, the ethnic minority development plan or ethnic minority specific actions will be 
prepared in accordance with ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). 
 
Affected Persons 
According to the Government’s prefeasibility studies, the proposed projects involve the construction of four to six lanes for the 
GMS  Ha Noi–Lang  Son  and  Ha  Long–Mong  Cai  Expressways  and  up  to  eight  lanes  for  the  Ben  Luc–Long  Thanh 
Expressway. The total lengths will be about 120 km for the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son Expressway and the GMS Ha Long–Mong 
Cai Expressway and about 60 km for the Ben Luc–Long Thanh Expressway.  
Therefore, the three expressway projects will require considerable land acquisition: around 250 hectares (ha) of mainly 
agricultural and forestry land for the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son Expressway; 290–320 ha of mainly forestry and aquaculture 
ponds for the GMS Ha Long–Mong Cai Expressway, according to the option chosen; and 710 ha of mainly agricultural and 
aquaculture ponds for the Ben Luc–Long Thanh Expressway. Residential land will also be affected in all projects. 
The number of affected households is currently unknown but is expected to be higher than 1,000 for each of the three 
expressway projects. For the three expressway projects, resettlement should be under category A, and a full resettlement 
plan will have to be conducted for each project. 
 
HIV/AIDS 
The GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son and Ha Long–Mong Cai expressway projects will increase the inter-border traffic between the 
People's Republic of China (PRC) and Viet Nam, which could also increase the risk of the spread of HIV. As in border areas 
between  many  countries,  AIDS  prevention  and  control  is  challenging,  in  part  due  to  high  mobility.  According  to  a 
nongovernment organization (NGO) report,d Lang Son province is reported to have one of the highest rates of HIV prevalence 
(1.4%) in the country after Quang Ninh, Hai Phong, and Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC). The risk of HIV transmission in the border 
areas of Lang Son province is likely to remain high in the coming years because HIV transmission occurs not only among the 
commercial sex workers and intravenous drug users but also among clients and the general population. Quang Ninh province 
has the third-highest number of people living with AIDS in the country.  
 
The situation for the Ben Luc–Long Thanh Expressway Project is different. Even if HCMC has the highest HIV rate in the 
country, the two districts belonging to HCMC which are crossed by the expressway are rural districts with slow urbanization 
and industrialization and with few AIDS cases. This expressway will also not create new pathway for diseases as it is mainly a 
ring road around HCMC. 
 
Human Trafficking 
Lang Son and Mong Cai are two important gateways for human trafficking (especially women) between Viet Nam and the 
PRC. According to a survey by Save the Children UK and the Youth Research Institute,e poverty was the major factor leading 
to human trafficking, as persons seeking opportunities for higher-paying work outside of their home provinces are vulnerable 
to being deceived into trafficking situations. Other factors contributing to the problem include lack of education and low 
awareness among women of the dangers. Many victims of trafficking were single women who legitimately wished to get 
married, while many Chinese men are bachelors seeking wives. The GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son and Ha Long–Mong Cai 
Expressways will increase the inter-border traffic between the PRC and Viet Nam. An awareness campaign should be 
conducted among the population. NGOs such as Save the Children UK should be associated with this campaign. 
 
The Ben Luc–Long Thanh Expressway is quite a distance from the border area; however, the economic growth as a result of 
the expressway will increase migration in the project area. The migrant laborer may face risk of human trafficking.  
 
The social analysis will include the risks of the spread of HIV and potential increase in human trafficking for all the three 
expressways projects. Assessment of HIV and human trafficking will include (i) the current prevalence of HIV in the project 
area; (ii) the type and level of vulnerability of the population along the proposed expressway to HIV (disaggregated by gender, 
ethnicity, age, type of occupation, mobility, etc.); (iii) current human trafficking situation and the potential increase in human 
trafficking as well as increase in migration in and out of the project areas; (iii) review of provincial plans and activities on 
HIV/AIDS and human trafficking; (iv) review of existing programs of donors and nongovernment organizations on HIV/AIDS 
and human trafficking; (vi) recommendations for activities related to provincial plans and links with other development 
partners’ programs for preventing and mitigating the impacts; and (vii) assessment of the capacity-building training needs of 
relevant agencies for anti-HIV/AIDS. An HIV/AIDS awareness and human trafficking prevention program in the construction 
sites and the towns and villages along the expressways will be prepared for the investment loans.
